text: So if we had four affordances up, down, left, right, time horizon of two, there'd be 16 affordances.

text: And we're going to update the policy prior into the policy posterior.

speaker: SPEAKER_02

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So different policies might be evaluated to have different pragmatic values and different epistemic values.

speaker: SPEAKER_02

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: How many styles should we spin up?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So in the extreme case, there's only one style of zero, one style of one, one style of two.

text: That's just like a big circle around the points in space.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: On the other extreme, like every single example is its own style.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: How many styles are there?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And so then the question is, how do you find that sort of Pareto optimal, Bayes optimal number of styles that actually provide you positive classification ability?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And so that's sometimes approach from this idea of, on one hand, adding a latent factor and seeing if there's variability that that latent factor can explain.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then testing using Bayesian model selection.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Okay, here's my model with n styles.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Here's n plus 1 style.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Is that extra style punching above its weight?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Or if it's diminishing returns, then the smaller model is better.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So that's the kind of like add a latent factor, see if it helps.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: and then move forward with whichever one's better.

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then you remove the least informative of the parameters that you have.

text: So we already have a data set of people typing and their eye movements or of the mouse in the maze or the particle moving or whatever it is.

text: So we already know what data we want to connect from.

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Like we want to have the location observation at every time step.

text: So you could pre-register that model or you could build it after the data were collected
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then what's called model inversion is, so here is distribution of the parameters given the observations and actions.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then that is being flipped, it's proportional, that's the kind of infinity sign, to here's the probability of the parameters given the model, and then the probability of the actions given the observations in the model.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And so then this is reconstructing latent parameters theta in this kind of general linear regression framework against the observations, conditioned upon the observations.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So when we're generating synthetic data, you can think about that as a distribution of observations conditioned upon parameters.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Like I'm just saying that the room is 30 degrees and now I'm going to generate noisy thermometer data.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So that's like generate me thermometer observations conditioned upon the hidden state S. The other way to do an inference, the inverted model would be, tell me what you can say about S, the true temperature in the room conditioned upon these observations that I'm empirically getting.

text: So those are kind of the two directions of using a Bayesian model.
